item.title: Tutorial Intro
item.description: Let's discover Docusaurus in less than 5 minutes.
item.content:encoded:
Let's discover Docusaurus in less than 5 minutes.

Getting Started​

Get started by creating a new site.

Or try Docusaurus immediately with docusaurus.new.

What you'll need​

  • Node.js version 14 or above:
    • When installing Node.js, you are recommended to check all checkboxes related to dependencies.

Generate a new site​

Generate a new Docusaurus site using the classic template.

The classic template will automatically be added to your project after you run the command:

npm init docusaurus@latest my-website classic

You can type this command into Command Prompt, Powershell, Terminal, or any other integrated terminal of your code editor.

The command also installs all necessary dependencies you need to run Docusaurus.

Start your site​

Run the development server:

cd my-website
npm run start

The cd command changes the directory you're working with. In order to work with your newly created Docusaurus site, you'll need to navigate the terminal there.

The npm run start command builds your website locally and serves it through a development server, ready for you to view at http://localhost:3000/.

Open docs/intro.md (this page) and edit some lines: the site reloads automatically and displays your changes.

item.title: Welcome
item.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.
item.content:encoded:
Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the blog directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to authors.yml.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

  • 2019-05-30-welcome.md
  • 2019-05-30-welcome/index.md

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

The blog supports tags as well!

And if you don't want a blog: just delete this directory, and use blog: false in your Docusaurus config.

item.title: MDX Blog Post
item.description: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.
item.content:encoded:
Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.

tip

Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts.

print("Hello World!")

print("Hello World!")

item.title: Long Blog Post
item.description: This is the summary of a very long blog post,
item.content:encoded:
This is the summary of a very long blog post,

Use a <!-- truncate --> comment to limit blog post size in the list view.
